When we look at the health and safety impacts of nuclear power versus coal power, the data clearly shows that coal power causes far fewer deaths per unit of energy produced.

The coal industry has continually improved its safety practices over time to minimize risks to workers and nearby communities.

In contrast, nuclear power remains a relatively new and unproven technology. While nuclear accidents are rare, when they do occur, the consequences can be absolutely devastating. More recently, the Fukushima meltdown in 2011 also caused significant loss of life and long-term health impacts.

Moreover, the mining and burning of coal, while it does release pollutants, the health impacts of these are relatively localized and can be mitigated with proper safety measures. Coal power's impacts are also much more predictable and easier to manage compared to the potential for catastrophic failure at a nuclear facility.

Leaks and accidents at nuclear waste sites pose health risks for generations. Coal power does not have this issue - coal ash and other waste can be safely contained and managed.

In summary, while no form of energy is without risks, the evidence shows that coal power causes fewer deaths and less severe health impacts per unit of energy compared to nuclear power. Coal is a reliable, proven technology with predictable and manageable risks, while nuclear power's safety record and long-term waste issues make it a much riskier proposition. For the sake of public health and safety, coal power remains the preferable choice.
